data.title: Project MUSE
data.text:
Ira Allen is Assistant Professor of Rhetoric and Composition at the American University of Beirut. His research moves between rhetoric, political theory, translation, and writing studies, and appears in Advances in the History of Rhetoric, Theory & Event, Political Research Quarterly, SubStance, Modern Language Notes, and elsewhere. He is author of The Ethical Fantasy of Rhetorical Theory (forthcoming, University of Pittsburgh Press). Ira can be reached at gjc43@drexel.edu

Thomas Biebricher is temporary Professor of Political Theory and Philosophy at the Goethe-Universität in Frankfurt. He has published numerous articles on neoliberal theory and practice and is he is author of an Introduction to Neoliberalism (in German) published by Junius (2nd edition, 2015). He currently completing an edited volume called The Birth of Austerity: The Ordoliberal Contribution to Contemporary Neoliberalism, (forthcoming, y Rowman and Littlefield International). Thomas can be reached at thomas.biebricher@normativeorders.net

Willy Blomme is the Program Director at the Broadbent Institute, Canada's leading progressive, independent think tank. She holds a PhD in Political Theory and International Relations from Johns Hopkins University. Her academic work examines the challenges to belonging, attachment and identity created by the climate crisis and delves into areas such as new materialism, contemporary political theory, environmental politics, place, weather and art. She is currently completing a book manuscript titled Eulogy for Winter for the McGill-Queens University Press. Willy's email address is willy.blomme@gmail.com

Kevin Bruyneel is Professor of Politics at Babson College in Massachusetts. He wrote The Third Space of Sovereignty: The Postcolonial Politics of U.S.-Indigenous Relations (University of Minnesota, Indigenous Americas Series, 2007) and writes on the relationship between race, colonialism and collective memory. He is working on a book manuscript on White Settler Memory in the United States. He can be reached at kbruyneel@babson.edu, and his faculty website is here: http://www.babson.edu/Academics/faculty/profiles/Pages/Bruyneel-Kevin.aspx

George Ciccariello-Maher is Associate Professor of Politics and Global Studies at Drexel University in Philadelphia and currently visiting [End Page 571] researcher at the Institute for Social Research at the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM). He is co-editor, with Bruno Bo-steels, of the Duke University Press book series Radical Américas, and author of We Created Chávez: A People's History of the Venezuelan Revolution (Duke, 2013), Building the Commune: Radical Democracy in Venezuela (Jacobin-Verso, 2016), and Decolonizing Dialectics (Duke, 2017). George can be reached at gjc43@drexel.edu

Paul Earlie is a Postdoctoral Research Fellow in French at the University of Chester. He has previously held research positions at the University of Oxford and at the Université libre de Bruxelles. He is the author of several articles, a forthcoming monograph, Spectres of Freud: Between Psychoanalysis and Deconstruction, and a special issue of the Revue internationale de philosophie on psychoanalysis and literature (forthcoming, 2018). His current research concerns rhetoric and the politics of theory. Paul can be reached at earliep@tcd.ie

Leonard Feldman is Associate Professor of Political Science at Hunter College and the Graduate Center, CUNY. He is the author of Citizens Without Shelter: Homelessness, Democracy and Political Exclusion (Cornell, 2004). He is currently the Associate Editor for Political Theory of Polity. His work has appeared in Political Theory, Law, Culture and the Humanities Polity, and various edited volumes. Prior to CUNY, he was a Mellon Foundation post-doctoral fellow at Grinnell College, and an assistant and an associate professor at the University of Oregon. From 2007 to 2008 he was a member of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton. He can be reached at lenniefeldman@gmail.com

Todd Hoffman is an associate professor at Augusta University in Georgia, USA. His areas of interest include the philosophy of Gilles Deleuze and Felix Guattari, Marxist and psychoanalytic theories, postmodernism, and contemporary American literature. He is currently working on Deleuze's ontology and its interpretive and structural uses in examining literature, in particular notions of flight or escape from totalizing social systems. He has recently published in cTheory, also on Mark Fisher's book, and has a Deleuzian analysis of François Ozon's movie Young and Beautiful as a chapter contribution...
